title: Took a little getting used to but now I love it
text:
Initially I had trouble connecting SMTP mail servers. I kept getting password error messages and occasionally connected email profiles would disconnect and the problem would start all over again. For no reason that I could fathom, the exact same credentials (pasted) would then suddenly start working again. This seems to have settled down now and things are working as they should. 

At first the interface seemed clunky but after getting used it it feels very efficient. 

Pros: 
Spam control!
My biggest complaint against Apple’s mail app is complete lack of spam recognition. No matter how many times you junk spam emails, the same stupid emails keep showing up in the inbox several times a day. Blocking senders is pointless because every junk email has a unique sender. The Outlook app did away with most of them after just one junking session! Sweet!

Functionality
Although the app takes a little exploration to find where things are and how they work, it has many of the bells and whistles of the desktop app. 

Cons:
Inability to sort threads from newest to oldest. Judging by forum posts spanning many years, this is a long standing gripe among users. But I’ll trade it for spam recognition any day.

title: It’s possible it could be worse I guess…
text:
This might be the worst app on my phone. 

Number one, the search function is garbage. You can literally search the same term in the desktop version and in the app version and get utterly different results. My main result using the app search is literally nothing, even when I’m using sender email or contents of email. I guess it could be worse but if you are without desktop access and need to find an email older than this week or month, good luck. 

Number two, there is no interoperability between iCal and outlook. If you’re using a secure email system and can’t link the account to your mail app, you have no way of using the calendar. So you end up having two calendars on one phone. I’m pretty sure not having to do this is one of the main benefits of a smart phone, but i guess Apple and Microsoft still hate each other more than they care about customer service, so you can’t get outlook events in your Apple calendar. Or vice versa. Has led to me missing several appointments as a result.

Finally, for whatever reason printing and PDFing within this app is extremely clunky. You basically have to trick it into triggering apple’s native pdf creation in order to get it to work properly. I don’t know why it’s so difficult to just forward attachments or other documents but it’s not great. 

It does the job so I’m not giving it 1 star, but the user experience vastly underwhelms.

title: Great email app for all my fellow road warriors
text:
I don’t review apps often, but since starting a new job that lets me use the native Outlook app to it’s full potential versus a different email client (BlackBerry Work), I’m blown away. 

The real feature I want to highlight is the Cortana integration for audibly reading and actioning your mailbox. As an employee who’s always in the car if not in front of my desk, having the ability to listen to your inbox and action emails is HUGE. I’ve seen simple dictation and some minor features that let you delete an email, but the features for actioning emails with your voice and it’s ability to keep email conversations grouped together is the best I’ve ever seen. 

If you’re an on-call employee or find yourself needing to check emails on the road, this is a superb application.

title: Very handy!
text: This app is great for helping me get work done on the go. I have two different accounts linked to it, and I think it does a great job of helping me access both and keep things organized. The only two complaints I have are things that only recently started happening, so I think they’ll be sorted out with a new update. The first is when I add a link to an email, I get a spinning circle, like the app is thinking, and I can’t type anything after it without having to back out of the email and then go back into the draft. The other is if I copy and paste something else into the email that is a different font color/style or comes up as a different font color/style, I can’t change the font color/style to match everything else. It would be nice if they included a “clear formatting” option for the app. Otherwise, this is great.

I’ve had no problems with the iOS default mail app, Outlook online, and the Office 365 PC Outlook application.  Very disappointing since it previously worked so well.  Finally support responded by noting the issue and closing the case with no solution or work around.  I pay for Office 365 yearly and this is the support I receive???

title: Should be five stars except that
text:
They have a great email folder search mechanism for moving emails from one folder (such as inbox) to another folder for storage purposes but they could/should have the same email folder search mechanism for simply locating a specific email folder that is constantly positioned at the top of the PC or smartphone screen of the list of email folders (even if I am anywhere in the folder list).

Having used this Microsoft email system for over fifteen years I have created/accumulated hundreds of email folders and to be able to search the email folders list the same way that it already lets me search through all my stored emails content for a specific name, phrase or whatever would be both a fantastic time saver and a helpful reminder of what I have available for review and use.

Keep up the good work.

text:

title: Best email app (if you are in the microsoft ecosystem)
text:

title: In a time of so many working apps...
text:
In an age in which there are so many apps that one can download to their phone, why would anyone choose to use this.

Glitchy, constantly crashes.  Very poorly organized.  What I mean is that every time I update this app I have to go into the setting menu and turn off the featured email, feature. Because that feature is worthless.  It makes it hard to get to my newest emails, or god forbid I want to find an old email.

This app is slow to load, slow to maneuver, and just generally unpleasant to use.  

It seems to have trouble connecting to the outlook servers, so that often emails that I have deleted are still in my inbox when I sign back in, although the app does like to move them to the featured list.  So the emails that I definitely don’t want I am sure to see every time I log in.

Then if you are silly enough to try to edit your archive, or really any of your folders, don’t select more that two or three to move or erase at a time, because the app can’t handle you selecting more than that.  It will crash and you will have to start all over.  

Just a bad app.  I think that you would be better off with one of those free kinda crappy email apps.  At least they don’t pretend to be useful or awesome.

title: No alias support and doesn’t play nice with Google calendar invite
text:
I would rank this app higher except the two problems above are a significant challenge.

*on my outlook desktop, I can send an email from my server with a different “reply to” address shown as the sender. But that is not built yet on the iOS app. This is definitely a problem for my business. I have to do all of one specific type of email from my computer instead of my phone.

*when I receive invitation from Google, I have to accept them on my computer or they don’t save properly to my calendar. They show on my calendar, but they don’t have the event details and information saved correctly. This is a MAJOR pain point for me as I can’t accept any Google calendar invites on the fly.

*no longer shows my Facebook events correctly in my calendar, which is bothersome. Again, I have to go back to the computer to save to my Google calendar because Facebook calendar display isn’t reliable. 

What I do love, is the ability to create new events in the calendar of my choosing. That definitely helps. 

I just wish I could *save* events to the calendar of my choosing or default a calendar for non-Gmail addresses (since outlook doesn’t like working with cpanel calendars).

title: Otherwise Excellent App can't Alphabetize Contacts...
text:
Microsoft Outlook has quickly become one of my most frequently used iPad apps.  For those familiar with any of the PC (or Mac) based versions of the program, the Outlook app will be highly intuitive.  Microsoft releases regular updates that address reported issues and which make the app increasingly useful and navigable.

My only real complaint has to do with an ongoing problem of late in the app's handling of email images.  Often, placeholders are all that appear.  I have looked into security settings and other possible causes for this and cannot resolve the situation.  (Many other complaints from other users of the Outlook app about the glitch are documented online.)  The problem does NOT impact the native Apple Mail app, which displays email images just fine when used instead.  Only Outlook exhibits this image-related problem.

title: A few warts on a solid app
text:
As others have noted, there is little meaningful interaction between iOS data stores (most notably Contacts) and Outlook. This balkanizatiom of data within the app needlessly adds extra steps (as when adding a contact from a received email).

Calendar and email synchronization is solid, on the whole, but unlike the iOS Calendar, you can not choose which Google calendars shared with you are synced (it's all or nothing).

Visually, it's a bit above par and the UI elements are intuitive, following brief adaptation. Presentation of attachments is better than in Mail. The options to override the default browser and navigation apps are very much appreciated. Search is not the best, but arguably a tiny bit better than desktop Outlook.

Finally, there is the mail setting that drives me a little nuts: Reply All is the default when there was more than one recipient of the email you're replying to. 
No, just no. 
Reply to all is a huge time sink and makes every organization less efficient. I'm so anti-Reply All that I think you should have to take a four hour class and pass a test just to get the button turned on. Please, Microsoft, do us a solid and make reply the default. If my co-worker really is going inflict their opinions on the whole 38-person list, at least let it be intentional.

title: Some issues
text:
I’ve been using Outlook as an alternative to the built in iOS mail app due to recent vulnerabilities discovered in the latter. Generally it’s ok, but I find some things less usable:
1) longer emails display a “Read More” button after scrolling part of the message. This is completely useless and requires unnecessary clicks. There’s no reason not to simply scroll the entire message. 
2) after deleting a message, the app returns to the message list. There should be an option to read the next message, again to avoid extra clicks to read your emails. 
3) no indication when the app checks for new messages, and doesn’t show last-update time. I’m used to iOS app clearly indicating this, so similar function would help here. 
4) delete button in upper right when reading message: this is a personal issue, in that when holding my iPhone XR with my left hand, I cannot easily reach the delete button.

title: Outlook Review
text: I struggle with outlook bc my school uses them and I had chosen them for an email account, but the app is so slow and does not work whatsoever.  You would think that if your college and Microsoft can partner with them, it would be an outstanding service overall, but unfortunately I have discovered the Outlook app does not live up to the potential. You go to login to the app, and NONE of your new emails pop up, only emails from days or weeks prior, it lags when sending an email or receiving one. And the worst part is when you get an Outloook notification from your professor and cannot open it because Outlook refreshes constantly to say you have no new mail.  Honestly, for a student with a full time job that needs an immediate view and notification, I would not recommend Microsoft Outlook by any means. Even updating the app does not fix this issue. Very disappointed.

title: Classic Email Client ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️
text:
I have used Microsoft Outlook for more than 15 years both on computer and mobile applications. Outlook is an easy to use application with simple step by step screen options to add just about any email account.
As other reviewers have mentioned, it would be very nice to see the Outlook Calendar sync with the mobile phone Calendar just as the Gmail application does, as we would not need to use a separate setup to sync our Calendars.
Another wish would be to see Outlook have the capability of moving emails across email accounts. Just like the desktop Outlook application does, it would be helpful to copy over, or move emails, from one email account to another, on my mobile phone.
Note: as of July 28, 2020 I have an iPhone 6s running Microsoft Outlook from the App Store

title: A gem marred by fundamental problems
text:
This app is superior to the built in iOS Calendar and Mail apps in almost every way.  And yet I use it infrequently, only when I really need its capabilities.  I’d love to use it exclusively.  So why don’t I?  Three big reasons.  (1) it’s slow to start.  When I open Mail, it’s always there. No load time.  When I open Outlook, I can wait 1-3 seconds for the darn thing to load if it hasn’t been active recently.  That’s a drag. (2) what’s worse, the messages are not auto downloaded.  So I open the app, then wait for 5-10 seconds or pull down to refresh and wait 5 seconds to see new messages.  What?  Why?!  (3) minor... but I’d like to have calendar and mail separately so I can look up my calendar while responding to an email.  

Microsoft, please, please solve at least issues 1 and 2 and I will happily carry the banner of Outlook for iOS.  Until then you are just upsetting me but giving me such a fantastic app that I can’t use effectively due to these major flaws.

title: Sort order within a conversation
text:
Edit
Just reinstalled Outlook again and I see where after what is now approaching nearly nine years, one still can’t sort conversation threads properly. Uninstalling and reverting back to the default iOS Mail app. Fingers crossed it’ll be fixed when I look again in a few months. 

We're two days away from the six-year anniversary of Microsoft's rebranding of Acompli and theystill haven't fixed the sort order within a conversation thread. Newest emails belong at the top of the thread as it is in the desktop version (and as it was in WM as well). Even the default iOS mail app gives you the option. And why does your account icon show a picture when you have contact photos enabled and only one account but a letter when you have more than one - both my work and personal account descriptions start with same letter (I'm supposed to remember which color refers to which account - and yes, I can change the account description, but I shouldn't have to).

title: Not Ready For Prime Time
text:
I downloaded and tried the latest version because I use Outlook on my PC and like it there. To my surprise, however, unless Exchange is being used, there is no syncing with an Outlook calendar on the PC. I am not using Exchange, so my workaround was to add my iCloud account and then have it sync with my PC running iCloud for Windows. No joy. Syncing of "all day" events was random and arbitrary at best.

Nor does the app support syncing with the PC's Task list even if (I believe) the user is on Exchange. This is a major issue for me.

Finally, the app does not play well with IMAP email accounts. First, it took a ton of time to set up the account because the "automatic" setup did not work. In the end I opted to set the account up manually, but it still took several tries. Once up and running, receiving emails seemed ok, but on average over 45 seconds would elapse before I heard the chime notifying me that my email had been successfully sent. Repeated re-adding and re-setting of the IMAP account did nothing to move the "sent" elapsed time any closer to the normal 5 seconds needed by the native IOS Mail app.

In summary, if you play in both the Apple and Microsoft worlds, there are better alternatives out there. That said, the idea of Outlook on the iPhone is a worthwhile one. I I hope Microsoft will address Outlook's issues and shortcomings in the near future. Until then, though, I'll continue to use Mail and Calendar.

title: Keeps me on track!
text: Love the focused inbox feature of this email app. I would be lost for hours searching through my coupon emails and other subscriptions. Now I can keep my subscriptions in their place when I need and want to view them but important emails from doctors, teachers, scheduled meetings, etc are in the forefront daily. I was lost without this feature before, always missing the important ones. Now I can check every morning and feel confident I’m on track! Only thing I’d love to change would be the calendar. I would like to sync calendar dates in an email to my iCal instead of using Microsoft calendar. I know I can manually input an event, but it would make it simpler to click on the date and give an option of either calendar for those apple users too. Thanks for a great email app!

title: Opening a link in email leads to internet search through outlook app. CHANGE THAT!
text:
When I click on a link that someone sends me through the email, it opens up to some sort of outlook internet explorer. I don’t want to search the internet from my email app! What happens when I need to go back and reference something in an email while I’m in Outlook internet search engine, or whatever it is. I have to exit out of what I was looking at and lose the spot that I was at while I was looking. I know there is a clickable button that sends me to safari but I don’t wand to make 3 extra click to do that. If I click on a link, that means I want to see that on the internet. 

You made Outlook difficult to use by adding this function to the Outlook email app. When I click on a link I want to go to my default internet explorer. I don’t want to search the internet through an email app. That’s just ridiculous. Remove that or give us an option to remove that. I haven’t figured out how to remove it.

title: Horrible
text:

Tried the new outlook on my computer as well and everything is just confusing now.
No wonder I stayed with Gmail. Will be switching my accounts over and deleting all these Microsoft attached things. Lost a customer and I’ll be sure to tell my friends and family to stay away if they don’t want CONSTANT UPDATE REMINDERS AND CONSTANT BIRTHDAY REMINDERS THAT WONT SAVE SETTINGS!! I’ve tried turning off birthday notifications and EVERY DAY at 12 o clock noon sharp I get stupid reminder dings and emails about birthdays when I TURN THEM OFF EVERY DAY. title: Cannot load messages fully, the search is very limited
text:
It's the greatest and most convenient unified email and storage app out there. But it has a serious issue with accessing and loading the emails. 
I have connected some Gmail accounts. One major problem is that it doesn’t load the messages fully. At the bottom of the message there’s a “tap to retry” bottom, but clicking that multiple times doesn’t do anything. 
Another major problem is searching. Its searching capability is very limited to the most recent emails. And when clicking on search for more, it doesn’t do anything ; although I know it should come up with more results. 
Also since a while ago, when opening an email, or switching from focused to others, it freezes for a couple of seconds, although I'm connected to a super fast internet.
It was a good app, but with these problems it left me no chance but to switch to another app or just load the email with browser.

title: Adjusted features could be helpful
text:
When using outlook on a browser it offers the option to pin an e-mail to the top of your messages. That feature doesn’t exist in the app or if it does I haven’t found it. 

When using outlook on the desktop app there’s an option to delay delivery but it isn’t available in the app or again I haven’t found it. 

The best thing that I would find helpful is if the calendar and e-mail functions were two separate apps!! 🙏🏽 because there are times when I need to check the calendar for availability but I don’t want to open my WORK e-mail. Because I’m setting a boundary for work-life balance and don’t want to get caught up in emails after hours or on weekends. 

 Also if writing an e-mail from the app, there are times when I want to switch to the calendar to check on dates. To do so I have to get out of the e-mail which sends it to drafts. I can check the calendar then I have to go to my drafts to find what I had been writing. This could be simplified if the two features were different apps and we could switch quickly between the two. 

These are features that would improve my user experience. 

Honestly I’m only using outlook because it is what my work requires but since it isn’t as user friendly then I usually just don’t prefer it.

title: It’s good but some room for improvement
text:
I love the app, but there are 2 areas of issue that I have with it that prevent me from giving it 5 stars. First off for government accounts it locks the app down to only allowing that 1 account to be added and thus no option for a personal account (which I use outlook for) and since it’s not a computer proper I can’t have a second copy of the app installed to use with my personal accounts…

Second, emails in folders other than inbox get forgotten every update. I have rules that send email all over the place and having to go select each folder every single time it updates to see if there is new email from those people is very frustrating. 

Aside from those issues it’s an awesome app.

title: Mostly Great. Need some fine tuning.
text:
I’ve been using outlook as my preferred email application for personal email for as long as I can remember. 

Recently however, due to tighter security protocols, I am required to use outlook as my work email application. I previously kept them separate by using different applications. So far having the two together is not a big deal because I can separate the two streams by using the profile feature. 

Buuuut...it would be really great if there were a way to differentiate between multiple accounts as to which one specifically has new mail on the icon rather then being forced to see both. I would like a way to shut off the ability to see a badge for new work emails while retaining the personal email counter. Right now it is all or nothing. Seems like an easy implementation to give people the option!

title: Having Problems Now
text: Overall, I loved this app for email much better than the iOS default app and even Gmail. It’s very intuitive with having calendar and email in one and the ability to add TV shows to your calendar and connect supported apps. I also really enjoy the custom swipe and being able to only get notifications from what gets filtered into my Focused Inbox. All that said, I have run into a problem. I send my hours to my employer through email and she isn’t getting the attachments at all even though I use Excel and it should work seamlessly! Sometimes she doesn’t even get my emails at all! I check my email sent folder and they are all there. I check my sent folder via my browser through Gmail  and not all the emails are there and so I use that to forward the email to her and she finally gets it. Can someone please help me out? I want to use this app for my email, but if it isn’t going to work I might as well go back to Gmail or something else.

title: Want an email app not a text app
text:
I use the Outlook app just for work email.  Don’t like the layout of the reply section which defaults to “reply all” and looks like a text box.  When I reply to an email, I need to decide up-front whether I need to reply to all, or just the sender, fwd, or add someone else in, etc.  This is possible but requires too many steps.  There should be a drop down with a selection of how you want to reply without having to reply to all initially and then have to change it later.

Also, the text box look is unnecessary for a professional email app.  I work in a professional office setting where emails are key to doing business.  I need to be able to see the full email I’m replying too and don’t need some new “hip” feature of it looking like a text box.  If some people want that, fine, then at least give layout options for those of us who want the usual MS Office Outlook functionality

title: Calendar’s okay, email is awful
text:
The calendar is useful, although I wish I could assign categories.  I try to use the desktop version to enter new appointments so I can categorize and annotate them fully.  But the app does a fine job reminding me of what I need reminding of.  The color-coding I entered on the desktop does *show* in the app I just can’t enter it there.  Why.

Composing an email in the app is an exercise in frustration every time.  The page doesn’t scroll down, so if I have more than 12 lines of things to say I’m typing blind.  Going back to edit you run the risk of just deleting your message altogether.  Yes, it’s in the drafts, but why would that even happen.  Infuriating.  I’ve just added my outlook email to Apple’s native email app and send my emails from there to avoid the aggravation.

Overall pretty crappy.  This is Microsoft we’re talking about.  Do better fellas.

title: Simple and clean
text: I really enjoy the overall interface of Outlook. It is super clean and simple! I personally never really liked the standard issued “mail” app that was imbedded in the iPhone, so I decided to download Outlook and use it as my go to email site and I haven’t had any issues with it at all. Opening and responding to emails through this app has been a joy! Being able to change the different notifications sounds when receiving and replying to emails has never been fun until I’ve used Outlook. The only thing that is preventing me from giving it a 5 star review is not being able to change the theme of your inbox (like gmail does with theirs),but ultimately it’s not really a big issue. In conclusion, I really like this app and don’t plan on going back to other email apps.

title: Much Improved, Almost Perfect
text: I’ve been an Outlook for iOS user since the beginning since I’ve used the desktop version since email was invented. This version is significantly improved with better synchronization to the desktop app when messages are read and moved. It also syncs perfectly with Apple Calendar and Contacts apps, making Outlook finally a complete, integrated personal assistant for phone and desktop. Definitely the best (and BTW free) app for managing mail, tasks, calendar and contacts in one place. And better than each of the standalone apps provided with the phone. My only concern is that messages saved to a folder in a different account can’t be accessed (replies, forward, etc.) from the original email account.

title: Can’t log in and customer support is garbage
text: Yesterday my email account kept having a pop up asking me to verify my password in my setting, so I went and put in my password. The next screen that popped up was one saying “someone has been trying to use your account please verify your account”. I do. Then it takes me back to the original log in page and I think I’m gonna get it but it happens all over AGAIN! Called customer support and was put on hold for about 40 minutes with the support tech getting back on the line about every 5 minutes asking me to continue to still hold. After about 35-40 minutes the representative gets on the line and gives me a phone number. Called the number and it would even connect. This is terrible customer service and I’ve been using this email for years and now have no way of getting in. Isn’t this Microsoft?! Not done Mom and pop company that you would EXPECT glitches from. What kind low level programmers do you have running that show over there?! FIRE THEM!

title: A couple HUGE gripes
text:
Great stable email solution. It's way better than apple's limited functions. Apple needs to get their act together for the business users. Regarding email address/people, I am finding I have to sync my iCloud contacts with exchange in order for autosuggestion of iCloud contacts. It doesn't utilize device contacts. Another lame issue..when I run a search in the sent items, it pulls out of every folder including inbox. AND they need to give us the option to put the most recent email at the top for Christ sake! Apple mail does this and it’s a lot more convenient for long email threads. Otherwise, I’m just scrolling and scrolling. And scrolling and scrolling!

Email threads: the newest email is displayed but doesn’t show the subject title. You have to scroll all the way to the first email in the thread to see the subject title. I rely on these titles!

title: Lots of great ideas - poor execution
text:
This is one of those rare times that I actually prefer the native iOS app. It’s weird that their desktop UI is pretty much perfect but their mobile app is horrid. 

To be clear, Outlook mobile has a lot of really great features. There was clearly a lot of time out into it but when it comes to using it, the UI is clunky and annoying to navigate. It’s one of those typical instances where engineers overbuilt something without considerations for streamlining it for actual day-to-day use. 

The way it displays previous replies is completely nonsensical. It takes forever to scroll up and down through the threads. It’s very easy to get lost. In the iOS Mail app, you could at least quickly snap to the top but here you need to manually scroll.  

It’s calendar functions are probably the worst part. It’s 3 day or 1 month. Who looks at their calendar in this increments? Yes, you can reorient the phone to get 5 day but again this seems like some engineer thought it was a great idea but never actually A B tested it. 

I switched back to iOS mail. After my wife tried using Outlook she convinced her IT dept to let her employees move back.

title: A powerful and useful mobile reflection of its desktop counterpart
text:
This app is incredibly useful and offers intuitive, powerful, and fully functional email, scheduling, and organizational utility. I primarily use this on my iPad, and I do wish that Microsoft would incorporate some of Apple’s own technologies (to the extent they are available for third-party developers) within. 

For example, I know that Apple allows users to open messages within the default mail app in a new window. While you can do that in Outlook, the functionality is not the same – it simply opens a new instance of the entire Outlook app. 

 All-in-all, this is a very useful app and a step in the right direction from Microsoft. I’m looking forward to seeing what more they can do, especially in the work of AI and as they update their suite of Office apps.

title: Okay for school; bad for professional
text: I used outlook throughout my college days and it got the job done. I just set up an account to have just for my business connections through my marketing firm. Long story short, after I tried to send an email that failed, I tried to send the email with proper email name and spelling; but I've been locked out of my account. Mind you that it was a government email which shouldn't send up any red flags; especially when it's a city official. I went through the protocol that they send you and still I'm locked out. When I messaged customer support through the chat, no response what so ever. So I'm giving them one star. If this was during my school time and I needed to message a professor or a Dean, I'd be furious. It's sad that we can't get responses or at least an automated check in to make sure it is us on the account so that we can verify and have our account available. Sad, sad, sad. I've switched my account to gmail and haven't had an issue yet.

title: Frustrating: Cannot delete old folders from email
text:
We are in 2023 and for some reason Microsoft doesn’t have the technology to delete old, empty, email folders. This is a feature that doesn’t exist. It’s extremely frustrating especially when I have to wade through a sea of irrelevant email folders that I would to delete. Creates a lot of unnecessary clutter.

Also, recently, the reporting system for junk, phishing, or menacing emails is not being manned by anyone at Microsoft. No matter how many times you report the same exact emails, Microsoft does nothing about them. Future emails do not go to the junk folder. They continue to show up in your in box, often multiple times within minutes of each other. The emails are the exact same ones that you reported days and weeks ago. I can’t believe they don’t have technology to catch these mass mailings and prevent them from being distributed. Microsoft has gone downhill in quality.

title: Not working
text:
I made the dumb decision to update the app, usually I never update because I know the update always doesn't help improve the app, just ruin the app with extra features and slows it down. But now I can't even use the app anymore at all whatsoever! I open the app and all I get is a blank white screen, nothing shows up, it's doesn't load anything except a white screen. It's been 2 days and I haven't been able to see what emails I have received at all without checking on my computer, updating was a complete mistake, i will update the app again when a new update shows up, hopefully it will fix whatever went wrong and then, never update again, because like I said before, updates never fix or improve and app, they just ruin in
0 STAR REVIEW

title: The calendar is basically useless
text: I'm really disappointed with the quality of the calendar part of the app. I don't understand why the desktop software, office 365 desktop version, office 365 mobile version, and iOS app calendars are completely different from one another. The iOS version is completely useless as a business calendar because I can't even add group calendars from my organization. How stupid is that? I'm deleting the app because it serves no purpose. I can view my emails just aa easily in a mobile web browser, and the calendar at least works moderately better. However, the desktop office 365 version is by far the best of the 3 viewable on mobile because it actually contains all of the information and functionality that the desktop software has. It's incredibly frustrating that I have to go to this level of manipulation of the web server just to perform basic tasks. This is extremely easy to do in other email apps like GMail, and those don't require a license. Hmmmm...

title: Amazing System!
text:
I am an iOS user. Using platform specific software has always been my mainstay. Try it and learn it. Whenever you learn something thoroughly, it enhances ones life.

When introduced to Outlook on a Mac, it was great because I could adapt quickly. However, on my new job, I’m using windows platform and Outlook has been seamless. Having to adapt to a windows platform was hard. Outlook made it simpler. It took a little while, and I will not turn back. I learn something new daily.

As a graphic designer, viewing is important. I have found the layout of the calendar in my emails and the alert I receive meet all of my needs. It looks more than just an email software. It encompasses chats, meetings, calendars, emails, and so much more.

title: Problems
text: Search works poorly. Emails I know are there don’t show up. Recent and most annoying, if you are reading an email, switch to another app and come back the email you opened had closed and you’ve gone back to inbox’s newest email. If you had searched for the earlier email you have to start searching all over again. Ugh! And, finally, an incredibly annoying and problematic problem:  if I’m drafting an email and move to another screen or app and come back to edit or continue writing, and try to place the cursor where I want to write, the cursor jumps to the very bottom of the screen even if the email chain is 10 emails long. I can’t get the cursor back to where I need it. Sometimes if I close the email and reopen it, it may work but only sometimes. Unbelievably frustrating. I haven’t talked to our company IT team about it yet, but this is becoming very problematic. Must be fixed. All this on iOS 13.3

title: Would rate 0 stars if I could
text: Im forced to use this email service for my university and almost every month without fail I get signed out of my account on the app. My university made us set up 2FA where it calls our phone to log back in and EVERY time the phone app signs me out, I’ll try to sign back in and answer the call and it will say my sign in verification was successfully completed but then it doesn’t log me back in and just tells me that there was an error and to “try again later”. I could wait for WEEKS and the error still wouldnt fix itself. Ive found that when this happens the only way to sign back in is to completely delete the app then redownload it. Sometimes even that doesn’t fix the issue until I’ve uninstalled and reinstalled the app 6 times within one day. Extremely unreliable and annoying. So glad I graduate in four months so that I hopefully never have to use this crappy excuse for an email service ever again

title: Needs to catch up with native iPhone apps
text: We were required to move to the Outlook app over the native mail app on our company devices. It took four days to get (almost) everything back. The calendar is definitely a downgrade from the native calendar. Contacts have to be re-imported and even if you have photos attached in Outlook on your PC, they don’t carry over. If you try to add a photo to the contact on your phone you find out that “photos are not supported”.  Really?  That should be an easy fix. And you can’t edit your contact from the contact list. The fix?  You have to create a second contact on your phone, add a photo and then link the two together. What a pain!  And don’t count on your notes from Outlook coming over. Nooooo, you have to download OneNote and connect to that so you can view them in the Sticky Notes. Come on Microsoft. This is why Apple continues to dominate the market.
